report_generation.note: Keyword-based check for DR/AMD/RVO mentions vs ground truth

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Warm, simple language; stays mostly within provided data; includes all required sections and generally appropriate “routine” framing.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Does not use the required natural frequency (“about 1 out of 10”) and doesn’t clearly explain probabilistic screening vs diagnosis; misses key next-step specifics (e.g., confirmatory dilated exam/retina follow-up) and omits notable ground-truth comorbidity (AMD) that Report B appropriately flags.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Warm, simple tone; uses the required natural frequency (“about 0 out of 10”); includes all required sections and generally matches key clinical values.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Introduces unsupported/overstated claims (e.g., “slightly elevated LDL” at 93 mg/dL; suggests obesity/LDL raise DR risk despite participant being healthy); fails to clearly emphasize screening vs diagnosis; downplays notable CGM hypoglycemia/variability and gives generic advice without addressing lows.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Uses the required natural frequency (“about 8 out of 10”), clearly labels this as a screening (not a diagnosis), connects eye risk to elevated HbA1c/CGM patterns, and includes all required sections in patient-friendly tone.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Less specific and practical next steps than Report B (no timeframe, fewer concrete instructions like dilated exam/what to say/what urgent symptoms warrant same-day care); CGM discussion is vague (doesn’t translate 44.2%/9.8% into natural-frequency terms); mentions “screening assessment confirms this likelihood” and “more advanced” without clarifying uncertainty, which could feel more definitive than needed.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Uses the required natural frequency (“about 1 out of 10”), clearly labels this as a screening with routine urgency, includes all required sections, and communicates CGM time-in-range appropriately.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Several clinical inaccuracies/mischaracterizations: implies diabetes is managed with medication (not stated as a conclusion), says total cholesterol is slightly above recommended (173 is generally not high), says LDL 80 is “a bit high” (typically acceptable/near-goal depending on risk), and states “good control” despite HbA1c 7.3% without nuance; action steps are somewhat generic compared with Report B.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Uses the required natural frequency (“about 1 out of 10”), clearly notes this is a screening (not a diagnosis), warm/simple tone, and includes all required sections with correct key values like HbA1c and CGM time-in-range.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Contains a major inaccuracy: claims triglycerides are healthy even though TG=250 mg/dL is elevated; also overstates “diabetes is well-controlled” (participant is prediabetes) and provides relatively vague next-step guidance compared with Report B.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Warm, simple language; includes all required sections; correctly uses the provided natural frequency (“about 0 out of 10”) and notes screening is reassuring.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Overstates conclusions (“eye health is generally good,” “don’t need to do anything special”) despite markedly worse left-eye vision and elevated BP/triglycerides; omits key data links (e.g., high BP/TG) and gives generic lifestyle advice not explicitly supported; doesn’t clearly frame screening vs diagnosis as strongly as Report B.

gpt5_judgment.strengths: Uses correct key values (A1c 6.3, CGM 99.5% in range, low DR probability), warm/simple language, clearly structured with all required sections.
gpt5_judgment.weaknesses: Does not clearly emphasize screening vs diagnosis (and suggests “don’t need to do anything specific right now” which can be misleading); CGM phrasing uses “time” but not “readings” as requested; “very early, mild stage” wording is slightly over-speculative given “no apparent retinopathy.”
